query: What evidence exists for the effectiveness of different strategies to combat white-nose syndrome in bats?
relevant_summary: One study in the USA found that a greater number of little brown bats infected with white-nose syndrome survived in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°C (1013). The same study also found that infected little brown bats stayed in hibernation for longer in hibernation chambers at 4°C than at 10°C (1013). Two studies have evaluated the effects of treating bats with a probiotic bacterium for white-nose syndrome (2008). One randomized, controlled study in Canada found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic at the time of infection increased survival and reduced disease symptoms in a laboratory setting. However, the same study found that bats treated 21 days prior to infection had worse symptoms (2008). A randomized, controlled study in the USA found that treating little brown bats with a probiotic in a mine increased the survival of free-flying bats, but not of caged bats (2008). The same study found that the severity of white-nose syndrome in caged bats was similar to that of untreated bats(2008). There were no studies found that evaluated the effects of culling bats infected with white-nose syndrome on bat populations (1012).

query: How do different methods for restricting public access to bat hibernation sites, such as gates versus fences, compare in their effects on bat populations?
relevant_summary: One study found that significantly more bats from two species emerged from a cave after a steel gate was replaced with a fence (1991), while another study found that significantly fewer bats emerged from a cave with a gate compared to one with a fence (999). In contrast, a replicated site comparison study in Spain found no difference in the population growth rates or occupancy of bats roosting in caves with or without fencing or gates (1991). Studies on gates found varied effects on bat populations. For mines, installing gates sometimes resulted in fewer bat species, fewer bats, and abandonment of the site, particularly with 'ladder' design gates (1963). Several studies noted that after gate installation at both caves and mines, bats would circle more at the entrances and enter less frequently (999, 1963). Gate design and bar spacing were found to influence how readily bats would fly through them (999). In one instance, bats hibernating in a gated cave lost more body mass than bats in a nearby unmodified cave (999). One study also discovered that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with the gates (1963).

query: To mitigate impacts from onshore wind farms, what are the most effective operational adjustments to turbines to reduce bat fatalities?
relevant_summary: Several operational adjustments to wind turbines can reduce bat fatalities. Ten of twelve studies in the USA and Canada found that increasing the wind speed at which turbines become operational, known as the 'cut-in speed', resulted in fewer bat fatalities compared to conventionally operated turbines [1960]. Two studies found that increasing cut-in speeds did not reduce bat fatalities, but these had small sample sizes or applied treatments for short periods [1960]. Five of six studies in the USA and Canada found that preventing turbine blades from turning at low wind speeds, a practice called 'feathering', also resulted in fewer bat fatalities [970]. One study found that feathering did not reduce bat fatalities [970]. In addition, one study in Canada found that slowing the rotation of turbine blades at low wind speeds reduced bat fatalities [2939].

Use (2 studies): One before-and-after study in the USA found that 43 of 47 mines continued to be used 12 years after gates were installed, however bats abandoned four mines with ‘ladder’ design gates. One replicated study in the USA found that gate design and time since gate installation had varied effects on the presence of four bat species.
Behaviour change (4 studies): Four replicated, before-and-after or site comparison studies in the USA and Australia found that bats at mine entrances circled more and entered mines less after gates were installed.

OTHER (2 STUDIES)

Collisions with gates (1 study): One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that up to 7% of bats at mine entrances collided with mine gates."
